title: Grand Jury
body:
Grand Jury

What is the Grand Jury?

The Civil Grand Jury is a division of the Superior Court, keeping watch over numerous government agencies, cities and districts throughout Santa Barbara County.

 

Who are Grand Jurors?

Grand Jurors are a diverse volunteer group of citizens from the five supervisorial districts. The community is best served by a mix of ethnic, gender, age and economic differences. 

Click for the Grand Juror Application Form.


What does the Grand Jury do?

The Grand Jury may investigate, evaluate and make recommendations to any city, county or special district agency that receives county funds. California law requires the Grand Jury to inspect County and city jails and detention facilities, and to review County financial accounts and records. The Grand Jury relies on its own discretion and citizens’ suggestions to determine other issues to investigate. 

 

How does the Grand Jury do its work?

The Presiding Judge of the Superior Court each July impanels 19 Grand Jurors to serve for one year, fulfilling the duties as outlined under state law. The judge appoints a foreperson who presides over the jury. The Grand Jury elects other officers and organizes itself. The Grand Jury meets in a weekly general session. Smaller investigative committees meet throughout the week.

 

How do I submit my concerns to the Grand Jury?

The Grand Jury is responsive to the suggestions and complaints from citizens about issues the jury should investigate. Each suggestion is reviewed by the full Grand Jury, or assigned to one of the jury’s committees for consideration. You can contact the Grand Jury through mail, phone, fax and email. Though the jury cannot investigate every issue, every comment is duly considered. 

Download the Complaint Form.

 

Will my comments to the Grand Jury be kept secret?

Grand Jurors are sworn to secrecy to protect the confidentiality of citizens who bring complaints against local government. The Grand Jury’s records may not be inspected nor subpoenaed. All Grand Jury investigations and interviews are kept secret. 

 

How does the Grand Jury release its reports?

The Grand Jury issues its final report each year in late June. The report is available to all county residents, and is delivered to the news media and to heads of affected government agencies. Affected agencies are required to respond to the report findings and recommendations within 60 to 90 days. Those responses are also available to the public. The Grand Jury may release individual reports as they are completed over the year. Grand Jury reports and responses are now available on the World Wide Web at http://www.sbcgj.org. 

 

For more information please visit the Grand Jury Web Site .

title: Tentative Ruling
body:
Tentative Ruling

Judge Donna Geck
Department 4 SB-Anacapa
1100 Anacapa Street P.O. Box 21107 Santa Barbara, CA 93121-1107

CIVIL LAW & MOTION

Jolene Romasanta vs Mark Romasanta

Case No: 19CV00450
Hearing Date: Fri Jun 03, 2022 10:00

Nature of Proceedings: Enforce Settlement

TENTATIVE RULING:

Plaintiff’s motion is denied in part, and moot in part.

 

 

Background: 

On January 25, 2019, plaintiff Jolene Romasanta filed a verified complaint alleging a claim against the estate of Anthony Nyman Romasanta, who died on January 25, 2018. Defendant Mark Romasanta is the executor of decedent’s estate.

On March 18, 2021, the parties filed a stipulation and proposed order to approve a settlement agreement. A copy of the settlement agreement was attached to the stipulation as Exhibit A. On the same date, the Court entered its order approving the settlement agreement and retaining jurisdiction to enforce its terms pursuant to Code of Civil Procedure section 664.6. Under the terms of the settlement agreement, defendant Mark Romasanta agreed to continue to administer decedent’s estate. Robert Traylor, counsel for plaintiff Jolene Romasanta, shall be paid $20,000 from the estate, and plaintiff shall be entitled to 20.5% of the net estate value upon final distribution. After approval of the settlement, defendant agreed to file a Petition for Final Distribution. (See March 18, 2021 Stipulation and Exh. A to Stipulation; Court’s March 18, 2021 Order.)

Plaintiff’s motion seeks an order, pursuant to Code of Civil Procedure section 664.6, entering judgment to require defendant to file a Petition for Final Distribution in case number 18PR00136, to pay Robert Traylor the sum of $20,000 within 10 days of an order on the motion, and to pay to plaintiff all reasonable fees and costs associated with the motion in the amount of $700. Defendant opposes the motion.

Analysis:

“If parties to pending litigation stipulate, in a writing signed by the parties outside of the presence of the court or orally before the court, for settlement of the case, or part thereof, the court, upon motion, may enter judgment pursuant to the terms of the settlement. If requested by the parties, the court may retain jurisdiction over the parties to enforce the settlement until performance in full of the terms of the settlement.” (Code Civ. Proc., § 664.6, subd. (a).) The parties to this dispute entered into a valid and binding settlement agreement. The Court has jurisdiction to enforce the settlement, and to enter judgment pursuant to the terms of the settlement.

Defendant states, and court records confirm, that a Petition for Final Distribution was filed by defendant in case number 18PR00136 on August 27, 2021. Therefore, according to the express terms of the settlement, defendant has fully performed the terms recited in the Court’s March 18, 2022 order with regard to filing a petition. On this basis, the motion is denied.

It appears based on information before the Court, that on May 20, 2022, after the motion was filed, defendant paid plaintiff’s counsel the amount of $20,000 pursuant to the terms of the settlement. (Vasquez Decl., ¶ 5, Exh. A.) As plaintiff has not filed a Reply to the Opposition, it appears to the satisfaction of the Court that defendant has complied with the terms of the settlement regarding payment to plaintiff’s counsel. Accordingly, on this basis the motion is moot.

In light of the Court’s ruling on this motion, plaintiff’s request for reasonable attorney’s fees and costs in the amount of $700, pursuant to paragraph 4.9 of the settlement agreement, is denied. Further, plaintiff has provided no information to permit the Court to assess whether the attorney’s fees and costs claimed by plaintiff are reasonable under the terms of the settlement (such as in a declaration by plaintiff’s counsel.)

Defendant has requested the Court receive oral testimony or hear oral argument on this matter. The parties may request oral argument in accordance with the Court’s procedures.

title: Tentative Ruling
body:
Tentative Ruling

Judge Donna Geck
Department 4 SB-Anacapa
1100 Anacapa Street P.O. Box 21107 Santa Barbara, CA 93121-1107

CIVIL LAW & MOTION

Stephen Duneier et al vs Robert Anthony Taylor, MD et al

Case No: 18CV03119
Hearing Date: Fri Jun 03, 2022 10:00

Nature of Proceedings: Petition for Approval of Compromise of Claim

TENTATIVE RULING:

The petition is conditionally granted in accordance with this ruling.

 

Background:

The complaint filed by plaintiffs Stephen Duneier and Barbara Duneier on June 21, 2018, alleges one cause of action for negligence against William C. Koonce, M.D. and other defendants who have since been dismissed from this action. As alleged in the complaint, on March 31, 2017, plaintiff Stephen Duneier was a patient under the care of William C. Koonce, M.D. (as well as other named but now dismissed defendants) when he suffered injury and damages due to the negligence of defendants through their diagnosis, treatment and care. (For purposes of this ruling, and for ease of reference, and not out of disrespect to plaintiffs, plaintiff Stephen Duneier will be referred to in this ruling as “Stephen”.) As a result, Stephen suffered a stroke and thereafter he was unable to walk, non-verbal, incontinent and requires 24/7 care. Plaintiffs allege that defendant William C. Koonce, M.D. (“Dr. Koonce”), and other dismissed defendants, were responsible for causing Stephen to suffer the damages and injuries alleged in the complaint, due to defendants’ failure to comply with the prevailing standard of care. Plaintiff Barbara Duneier, who is Stephen’s wife, also claims damages for pain, suffering and past and future medical expenses as well as lost earnings, and loss of consortium.

Petition:

Filed on March 23, 2022, the petition for approval of compromise of a person with a disability’s claim was filed by Stephen’s guardian ad litem and wife, Barbara Duneier, on his behalf. Stephen is currently fifty-four years of age.

The petition describes the events that occurred on March 31, 2018, while Stephen was a patient under the care of Dr. Koonce. At the time, Stephen was injured when Dr. Koonce was negligent in the diagnosis, care and treatment of Stephen, causing him to suffer a massive stroke. Stephen has suffered medical and other related expenses, lost wages and impairment of earning capacity, pain and suffering, emotional distress and impairment and enjoyment of life. The petition describes the care and treatment Stephen received for the injuries described in the petition. The petition identifies dates of treatment in 2017. The Court assumes this is a typographical error, and that all dates of care and treatment were in 2018, following the events of March 31, 2018.

Stephen was hospitalized from March 31, 2018 through May 4, 2018. Stephen was transferred to the California Rehabilitation Institute where he underwent rehabilitation from May 4, 2018 to July 6, 2018. On July 6, 2018, Stephen was medically transported to Memorial Rehabilitation Institute in Florida for further rehabilitation treatment through August 8, 2018. From August 8, 2018 to the present, Stephen has continuously required home healthcare, speech therapy, occupational therapy, and physical therapy as well as numerous follow-ups with specialists.

Attached as Attachment 8 are copies of reports from the Cleveland Clinic state that Stephen is wheelchair bound, has residual deficits over the right side of his body, was, as of 2019, demonstrating improvements in static standing and midline control, and that Stephen is in stable medical condition. Petitioner states that Stephen has not recovered completely from the effects of the injuries described in the petition. As a result of the stroke, Stephen is unable to walk, is non-verbal, incontinent, suffers from limited vision, and only has limited use of his left arm. Stephen’s condition is permanent.

Petitioner asserts that she has made a careful and diligent inquiry and investigation into the facts and circumstances of the incident in which Stephen was injured, responsibility for the incident, and the nature, extent, and seriousness of Stephen’s injuries. She understands that if the compromise proposed in the petition is approved by the court and consummated, Stephen will never be able to recover any more compensation from the settling defendant, even if his injuries turn out to be more serious than they now appear.

The total amount offered in settlement of both Stephen and Barbara Duneier’s claims by Dr. Koonce in this matter is $1,000,000. Petitioner is waiving any claim to a portion of the settlement proceeds pursuant to a Release of All Claims attached to the petition. Therefore, petitioner has no claim that would affect the proposed compromise of the claim described in the petition.

The total medical expenses, before any reductions, is $573,958.50. The total medical expenses paid are $398,951.28. The total of negotiated, contractual, or statutory reductions, is $307,799.10. Total medical expenses to be paid or reimbursed from the proceeds is $42,217.52. There are statutory liens totaling $42,217.52. A Non-ERISA insured plan paid the amount of $161.14. No reduction has been agreed to. Medicare paid the amount of $37,949.98, less a statutory reduction in the amount of $9,270.04, for a total reimbursement to Medicare in the amount of $28,679.94. There are one or more statutory or contractual liens of medical service providers for payment of Stephen’s medical expenses. The total amount claimed under these liens is $353,840.15. The lienholders have agreed to accept the sum of $13,376.44.

There are medical service providers who furnished care and treatment to Stephen who (1) have a lien for all or any part of the charges or (2) were paid (or will be paid from the proceeds) by petitioner, for which payment petitioner requests reimbursement. These medical service providers are Humana Medical Plan, Inc. (Florida Medi-Cal) (“Humana”), Medicare, and The Phia Group.

The petition states that the amount charged and paid by Humana is $353,640.16 and that there is a negotiated reduction of charges by Humana in the amount of $298,529.06. The amount to be paid to Humana from the settlement proceeds is $13,376.44. There appears to be a discrepancy in the amounts stated in petition paragraph 12.b.(5)(b)(i) regarding Humana’s lien and negotiated reduction. Based on the Faglie Declaration, it appears the correct amount of the Humana Medicaid lien was $353,840.16, and that Humana agreed to reduce its lien by $340,463.72, to $13,376.44. Counsel for petitioner is requested to address and explain this discrepancy at the hearing on the petition.

The amount charged by Medicare is $219,957.21. The amount paid is $37,949.98. There is a negotiated reduction of charges in the amount of $9,270.04. The amount to be paid to Medicare from the settlement proceeds is $28,679.94.

The amount charged and paid by The Phia Group is $161.14. There is no negotiated reduction. The amount to be paid to the Phia Group from the settlement proceeds is $161.14.

Based on the amounts charged and paid as stated in the petition, the total medical expenses, before any reductions, should be $573,758.51. If the correct amount Humana’s original lien was $353,840.16 as stated in the Faglie Declaration, then the total medical expenses before reductions should be $573,958.51. The petition states the total as $573,958.50. While this is a small discrepancy, counsel for petitioner is requested to explain these discrepancies and, if necessary, provide correct amounts at the hearing on the petition.

The total amount of attorney's fees, for which court approval is requested, is $222,755.94. The declaration of Todd F. Nevell is attached to the petition. Mr. Nevell declares that his firm was retained by petitioner/plaintiff Barbara Duneier and Stephen on January 18, 2018, to represent them in this medical malpractice action stemming from the medical care and treatment provided to Stephen leading up to and surrounding his stroke. Plaintiff Barbara Duneier, on behalf of herself and as power of attorney for Stephen, signed a retainer agreement with Scolinos, Sheldon & Nevell, a copy of which is attached to the petition. Mr. Nevell’s firm filed the complaint on behalf of petitioner and Stephen. The case was actively litigated over the past 4 years. Mr. Nevell reviewed and summarized over 2,000 pages of medical records, prepared and served responses to extensive written discovery, and prepared and served extensive written discovery. Mr. Nevell defended the videotaped deposition of plaintiff Barbara Duneier and took the videotaped deposition of Dr. Koonce. Mr. Nevell also consulted numerous medical experts and specialists. Mr. Nevell estimates, conservatively, that he has spent no less than 450 working on this case to date. The case settled for the full amount of Dr. Koonce’s professional liability insurance policy in effect at the time of the subject incident.

The attorney’s fees requested by Mr. Nevell’s firm represents 22.3% of the total recovery and is consistent with California Civil Code section 3333.2 (the Medical Injury Compensation Reform Act, or “MICRA”). Pursuant to MICRA, Mr. Nevell’s firm is requesting $222,755.94 in attorney’s fees to be paid out of settlement proceeds after reduction for litigation and consulting costs. Mr. Nevell’s declaration provides a calculation pursuant to MICRA. Scolinos, Sheldon & Nevell has advanced $28,528.01 in litigation costs to prosecute this action. This amount has not yet been reimbursed.

In addition, separate and apart from approval of the settlement of this case, petitioner seeks approval of dispositions to be made to experts and specialists retained in the State of Florida to prepare a Special Needs Trust on behalf of Stephen, and to defend against a large statutory lien asserted by Florida Medicaid to recover expenses related to Stephen’s post-stroke medical treatment received in the State of Florida. To ensure Stephen’s ability to qualify for future medical benefits in Florida will not be compromised by the California settlement, petitioner/plaintiff and Stephen retained Florida attorney David Lillesand to prepare the “Stephen Duneier Special Needs Trust” (“Trust”). A copy of the Trust is attached to the petition. Mr. Lillesand charged $6,500 to prepare the Trust. A copy of Mr. Lillesand’s invoice is attached to the petition.

To defend against the statutory lien asserted in the State of Florida by Humana on behalf of Florida Medicaid to recover medical expenses provided to Stephen in Florida, in August 2021, petitioner/plaintiff retained Florida attorney Floyd Faglie, a specialist in Florida Medicaid benefits. Mr. Faglie’s declaration is attached to the petition. Mr. Faglie declares that on August 16, 2021, he was retained by Stephen and petitioner who, as of that date, were residents of Florida, to resolve a $353,840.16 Florida Medicaid lien asserted by Humana. Mr. Faglie believes his firm is the only Florida firm that specializes in reducing Medicaid liens. A copy of the representation agreement signed by petitioner/plaintiff on behalf of herself and Stephen is attached to Mr. Faglie’s declaration. Pursuant to the representation agreement, the law firm of Staunton & Faglie, PL, agreed to charge a reduced fee of 20% of the amount of any reduction the firm was able to obtain in the lien. Mr. Faglie prepared to challenge the lien through an administrative hearing process under applicable Florida statutes, which is the exclusive means for reducing a Medicaid lien in Florida. Due to his experience and success in reducing Medicaid liens, Humana agreed to forego the litigation process and to compromise the payment of the lien. On September 20, 2021, Humana agreed to reduce its $353,840.16 Medicaid lien to $13,376.44. Pursuant to Mr. Faglie’s firm’s agreement with Stephen and petitioner/plaintiff, the total consulting charge was $59,705.81 (20% of the $298,529.06 reduction).

None of the medical expenses or attorney’s fees listed in petition items 12 and 13 have been paid by petitioner, for which reimbursement is requested.

In the Summary section (No. 16), the petition lists gross settlement proceeds of $1,000,000.00, from which expenses totaling $357,707.28 will be deducted (consisting of medical expenses of $42,217.52, attorneys' fees of $222,755.94, and costs of $92,733.82), for a net balance of $642,292.72 of proceeds for Stephen (No. 15).

Petitioner has been represented by an attorney in preparing the petition. Petitioner and the attorney have an agreement for services provided in connection with the claim giving rise to the petition, a copy of which is attached to the petition. The attorney does not expect to receive attorney’s fees or other compensation in addition to that requested in the petition, for services provided in connection with the claim giving rise to the petition.

There is no guardianship or conservator of Stephen’s estate. After payment of all statutory liens, petitioner requests that the court order the disposition of the balance of the proceeds of the settlement ($642,292.72) be paid or transferred to the trustee of the Trust established pursuant to Probate Code section 3604, for the benefit of Stephen. The terms of the Trust are specified in Attachment 18b(4).

Analysis:

A petition for court approval of a compromise of a claim by a person who lacks legal capacity to make decisions under Code of Civil Procedure section 372, or Probate Code sections 3600-3613, must comply with California Rules of Court, rules 7.950 or 7.950.5, as well as rules 7.951 and 7.952. (Cal Rules of Court, rule 3.1384(a).) The petition must be submitted on the approved Judicial Council form, verified, and “. . . must contain a full disclosure of all information that has any bearing on the reasonableness of the compromise, covenant, settlement, or disposition.” (Cal. Rules of Court, rule 7.950.) If the petitioner has been represented by an attorney in preparing the petition, the petition must disclose the information identified in California Rules of Court, rule 7.951(1) through (6), and the petitioner and the minor must attend the hearing unless the court for good cause dispenses with their appearance. (Cal. Rules of Court, rules 7.951 and 7.952.)

“The guardian ad litem's purpose is to protect the rights of the incompetent person.” (In re Christina B. (1993) 19 Cal.App.4th 1441, 1453.) In approving a guardian ad litem's settlement of an incapacitated person's claim, the trial court ensures the interests of the incapacitated party “ ‘have been fully and fairly considered.’ [Citation.]” (Carachure v. Scott (2021) 70 Cal.App.5th 16, 32.)

The Court has reviewed the petition and its attached documentation, including the Nevell and Faglie declarations, and attachments 8 and 18b(4). The Court finds that the $1,000,000.00 settlement with Dr. Koonce, made on Stephen’s behalf, is both reasonable and appropriate, and is in Stephen’s best interests. The Court further finds that the attorneys’ fees claimed for investigating and prosecuting Stephen’s claims, and settling the claim ($222,755.94), litigations costs, consulting fees to reduce the Florida Medicaid lien ($59,705.81) and fees to prepare the Trust ($6,500.00) are reasonable and appropriate.

The Court further finds that Stephen has a disability that substantially impairs his ability to provide for his own care or custody and constitutes a substantial handicap. Stephen is likely to have special needs that will not be met without the Trust. The amount to be paid to the Trust does not exceed the amount that appears reasonably necessary to meet the special needs of Stephen. The Court has reviewed and approves the terms of the Trust. The Trust satisfies the requirements of Probate Code section 3604.

Based on the above, the petition is conditionally granted upon counsel’s explanation and if necessary, reconciliation of discrepancies identified in this ruling. If counsel adequately clarifies the requested information at the hearing, the Court intends to grant the petition, and to order that the remaining balance of the proceeds of settlement ($642,292.72) be paid or transferred to the trustee to the Trust. The Trust is subject to the continuing jurisdiction of the Court under Probate Code section 15000 et seq. All statutory liens in favor of the State Department of Health Care Services, the State Department of State Hospitals, and the State Department of Developmental Services, or any county or city and county in this state shall first be satisfied.

title: Tentative Ruling
body:
Tentative Ruling

Judge Donna Geck
Department 4 SB-Anacapa
1100 Anacapa Street P.O. Box 21107 Santa Barbara, CA 93121-1107

CIVIL LAW & MOTION

Wells Fargo Bank NA vs Constance M Nash

Case No: 19CV05850
Hearing Date: Fri Jun 03, 2022 10:00

Nature of Proceedings: Case Management Conference; Motion for Summary Judgment

TENTATIVE RULING:  For the reasons explained below, the Court will set an OSC re establishment of venue for hearing on Friday, July 1, 2022, and will direct the parties to present the information requested below, no later than June 17, 2022.

 

 

Background: This action arises from a credit card which plaintiff issued to defendant on or about October 30, 2016, and which defendant used. Plaintiff’s complaint, filed October 31, 2019, alleges that defendant breached the agreement on or about April 4, 2019, by failing to remit any further payments on the credit card account. The complaint alleges causes of action for breach of contract and common counts (money lent, money paid, open book account, and account stated), and seeks damages of $6,160.67, and attorneys’ fees. The complaint alleges that the Santa Barbara Superior Court is the proper court because a defendant lives here now (i.e., at the time the complaint was filed.) The complaint was not served upon defendant until November 20, 2021.

An affidavit of unsuccessful service was filed on May 20, 2020, in which the deputy who attempted service upon defendant at 2169 Refugio Road in Goleta on December 26, 2019, declares that he was told that defendant Nash had been a renter at the premises, but had moved out in March of 2018. An affidavit of unsuccessful service was filed on April 19, 2021, in which the deputy who attempted service on defendant at 7127 Hollister Avenue, Suite 25A-26, in Goleta (a Mail Box store) on March 15, 2021, declared that the manager had informed him that defendant Nash had given up the mail box approximately 6 months prior.

A proof of personal service of the complaint was filed on December 6, 2021, indicating that defendant was personally served with summons and complaint on November 20, 2021, at 5785 Valley Drive in Felton, California.

Defendant answered the complaint on December 17, 2021, generally denying the allegations of the complaint. Her answer alleges that the Santa Barbara Superior Court is not the proper court for this action, in that she lives in Santa Cruz County.

Motion: By motion filed February 17, 2022, plaintiff seeks entry of summary judgment against defendant. The motion sets forth evidence with respect to defendant’s application for a credit card, and plaintiff’s issuance of the card to defendant, defendant’s subsequent use of the card and the making of payments on the account, up to April 4, 2019, after which no further payments were made on the account by defendant, although sums remained due to plaintiff pursuant to the agreement underlying the credit card account. The current balance due on the account is $6,170.67.

The billing statements submitted with the motion indicate that defendant Nash had lived at various addresses in Northern California and Maryland during the period she used the credit card. Of the billing statements attached to the motion, the statement for the billing period ending March 10, 2019, first showed an address of 2169 Refugio Road in Goleta. The statement for the billing period ending in May 2019 first showed the Mail Box store address at 7127 Hollister Avenue in Goleta.

The motion separately argues that the facts support entry of judgment in plaintiff’s favor on the breach of contract cause of action, and on all four common counts causes of action.

Defendant has not filed formal opposition to the motion, but has sought and received permission to appear via Zoom.

ANALYSIS: For the reasons explained below, the Court will set an OSC re establishment of venue for hearing on Friday, July 1, 2022.

The complaint in this case was filed on October 31, 2019. Shortly after the complaint was filed, plaintiff was unable to effect personal service upon defendant at the Refugio Road address in Goleta, and the deputy seeking to effect service of process was advised that defendant had moved out in March of 2018. Defendant had apparently arranged for receipt of mail at a Mail Box store for some period of time, but there is no evidence before the Court of where she was living at the time the complaint was filed.

Pursuant to Code of Civil Procedure section 395(b), an action arising from an extension of credit intended primarily for personal, family or household use, is properly venued in the superior court within the county where the contract was entered into, the superior court within the county where the defendant resided at the time the contract was entered into, or the superior court within the county where the defendant resided at the commencement of the action.

Pursuant to Code of Civil Procedure section 396a(b), if an action subject to Code of Civil Procedure section 395(b) is commenced in the wrong court, the court must transfer it to the proper court unless the defendant consents, either in writing or in open court, to keeping the action where it was filed.

There is no evidence before the Court that the credit card account was created by defendant’s execution of a written contract. The only evidence before the Court (the billing statements attached to the motion) also suggests that defendant did not live in Santa Barbara County at the time the contract was entered into between plaintiff and defendant.

It appears from the evidence before the Court that defendant was a resident of Goleta, within the County of Santa Barbara, at the time of her last payment on the credit card account on April 4, 2019. However, there is no information before the Court as to whether defendant was a resident of the County of Santa Barbara as of the time the complaint was filed on October 31, 2019, and in fact the process server was advised that defendant had moved out of the Refugio Road address in March of 2018. The remaining Goleta address to which plaintiff sent billing statements to defendant was a box at a Mail Box store, which does not provide any indication of defendant’s actual residence address, nor does it permit an inference that defendant was residing within Santa Barbara County at the time the complaint was filed in this action.

It appears to the Court that, if defendant was not a resident of Santa Barbara County at the time the complaint was filed, venue in this Court is improper, and the Court is required by the mandate set forth in Code of Civil Procedure section 396a(b) to transfer the action to a proper court.

Consequently, the Court will set an OSC re determination of the proper venue for this action for July 1, 2022, at 10:00 a.m. in this department.

On or before June 17, 2022, plaintiff Wells Fargo is directed to file with the Court any evidence, argument, or authorities it has with respect to the proper venue of this action.

Also on or before June 17, 2022, defendant Constance M. Nash is directed to file with this Court a declaration executed under penalty of perjury, in which she advises the Court of where she was residing on October 31, 2019, when she moved to Santa Cruz County, and any other information she believes to be relevant to this Court’s evaluation of the proper venue of this action. In doing so, Ms. Nash may, but is not required, to use the general Judicial Council form MC-030 for a declaration.

Nature of Proceedings: Petition: Appoint Temporary Conservator - Person and Estate

Probate Notes:

 

Appearance required. The following must be submitted:

 

Proof of Personal Service of the Citation. The notice must be personally delivered to the proposed conservatee at least 5 court days before the hearing. A copy of the petition for temporary appointment shall be served with the notice of hearing. [Prob. C. § 2250(e)(2)]

 

Proof of Timely Mailed Notice. Notice of the hearing shall be served five days prior to the hearing on the proposed conservatee’s spouse, parents, grandparents, children, grandchildren, and brothers and sisters (named in the Petition for Appointment of Conservator at ¶ 11). [Prob. C. § 2250(e)(2).]

 

Petition for Revocation of Advanced Healthcare Directive. Although it is recommended the Court grant Petitioner’s request to suspend the proposed conservatee’s AHD, this is only temporary relief that cannot be granted permanently without a Petition filed pursuant to Probate Code section 4766.Petitioner must file and serve the necessary petition under Probate Code section 4766 for permanent relief.

 

Capacity Declaration. A Capacity Declaration (GC-335) need not be filed for a temporary conservatorship. However, unless a Capacity Declaration is filed showing the Conservatee is unable to attend the hearing due to medial inability, the proposed conservatee must be present at the hearing. (Prob. Code, §1825.)

 

The proposed temporary conservatee is expected to attend the hearing. (Prob. Code § 2250.4.)

Public Index CD-ROM: Ordering Information

The Public Index CD-ROM is made available in its entirety on a monthly basis.

Daily updates are made only to the indices offered on public workstations located throughout the Courthouse. These workstation indices are updated daily with data as of 5:00pm the previous business day. They include only Non-Confidential cases.

The Public Index CD-ROM includes cases from 1975 for General Civil/Family/Probate and Criminal Felony cases, from 1997 for Limited Civil cases, and 1998 for Criminal Misdemeanor cases. There is a very limited number of cases filed as far back as the 1920s included in the Public Index . If you need to find a case with a file date prior to 1975, 1997 or 1998 as previously mentioned, please request a search of paper indices.

NOTE: "Due to the unification of Superior and Municipal Court records, there may be more than one case number for an individual or company, we advise that you look at all cases for that individual."

The Public Index CD-Rom shall not be re-copied or re-distributed without expressed consent from the Superior Court of California, County of Santa Barbara. The Court specifically disclaims any and all liability if the public index is purchased from a third party vendor.

The following information is available:

  • CIVIL / PROBATE / SMALL CLAIMS INDEX
    Names, case numbers, filing dates, case types and party types.

  • CRIMINAL INDEX
    Names, case numbers, filing dates, and party types.

  • MINOR OFFENSES / TRAFFIC INDEX
    Names, citation numbers, case types, filing dates

  • THE CD-ROM CONTAINS NO SOFTWARE. SEE THE TECHNICAL INFORMATION PAGE FOR IMPORTANT INFORMATION. THE SUPERIOR COURT WILL NOT PROVIDE TECHNICAL SUPPORT FOR THIS PRODUCT.

 

To order the CD-ROM:

  1. Download and print a copy of the ORDER FOR CD-ROM INDICES.
    You will need the free Adobe Acrobat Reader to view and print this document. If you need to get the Acrobat Reader, please visit the Adobe Website. 
  2. Complete and sign the order form. 
  3. Mail the completed form, with payment, per the instructions on the form.

body:
Tentative Ruling

Judge James F. Rigali
Department 2 SM-Cook
312-C East Cook Street P.O. Box 5369 Santa Maria, CA 93456-5369

PROBATE

Estate of Richard M Hernandez
Case No: 22PR00199
Hearing Date: Tue Jun 07, 2022 9:00

Nature of Proceedings: Petition: Letters of Administration

Probate Notes:

 

The following must be submitted:

 

1) Proof of Re-Publication. Proof of Publication is defective for multiple reasons that require re-publication. Jurisdiction of the Probate Court is obtained by publication in accordance with Probate Code section 8121. (Prob. Code, § 8003(b).) Publication requires the notice to be published in a newspaper adjudicated as a newspaper of general circulation in the city of decedent’s residence. (Prob. Code, §§ 8121, 7122.) Santa Barbara Independent has not been adjudicated a newspaper of general circulation in any city outside of the city limits of Santa Barbara, but Decedent was a resident of Santa Maria. A declaration of substantial compliance would normally be required (Prob. Code, § 8122) to remedy this defect, but the publication done by the SB Independent was also defective in that it did not contain notice that Independent Administration of Estates Act powers were sought by the petitioner. (Prob. Code, §10451.)

 

2) Proof of Service of Notice of Hearing (Form DE-121). Notice must be given 15 days prior to hearing, served on all known heirs and devisees, as well as on the Personal Representative (if not the petitioner) and special notice requestors. (Prob. Code, §§ 8100 & 8110.) Notice must be sent to the person, not the person’s representative. (§1220.) The Proof of Service on file shows service on only Decedent’s father and a person of unknown relation (Lisa A. Curtis) that was not listed in the petition. The petition, as discussed below, contains allegations showing the possible existence of unidentified heirs that must also be served.

 

3) Duties and Liabilities Acknowledgement (Form DE-147). The proposed personal representative must fill out and sign this form and submit it to the court. No such form was submitted.

 

4) Waivers of Bond. Bond must be waived by all adult heirs at law. Petitioner must file bond waivers (Form DE-142) for all heirs at law, whether they have priority.

 

5) Supplement to the Petition. The following allegations must be made without creating ambiguity, but were left blank or improperly alleged and must be corrected by supplement:

-       Paragraph 8 – A supplement to the petition listing all known heirs must be provided, even if those heirs are deceased. Paragraph 8 of the petition specifically requires listing even deceased heirs, and this Court requires heirs to the second degree, especially in intestate estates. The Court has discretion to require service to these heirs pursuant to Probate Code section 1202.

 

PLEASE NOTE: Siblings of Decedent must be listed, if any.

 

6) Proposed Order (Form DE-140). A proposed order must be submitted with relief that matches that requested in the petition. No such document was filed with the court.

 

7) Proposed Letters (Form DE-150). Proposed letters must be submitted with relief that matches that requested in the petition. No such document was filed with the court.

 

Because of the need for re-publication, it is recommended that the matter be continued to a date to be set by the Court at the hearing, unless the party appears and requests a different date, or submits a request for a different continuance date prior to the hearing. (Local Rule 1721(c)(2)(A-B).) If the matter is continued, documents must be submitted at least 10 days prior to the new hearing date to be considered.

Due to staffing limitations, processing times may be delayed. To assist in processing, attorneys and parties should include the next court date in the “Filing Description” field provided by the electronic service provider. That field is also used for further descriptions of the document being e-filed, so be sure to put the calendar date FIRST in the field – BEFORE any further description of the document being e-filed (e.g.: 06/28/16 For XYZ).

 

Appearances:

 

The court is open to the public for court business. Entry to any court building requires a face covering. The court is also conducting hearings via Zoom videoconference.

 

Zoom Appearances is allowed.

Tentative Ruling

Judge James F. Rigali
Department 2 SM-Cook
312-C East Cook Street P.O. Box 5369 Santa Maria, CA 93456-5369

PROBATE

Estate of Sachiko Matsuda
Case No: 22PR00202
Hearing Date: Tue Jun 07, 2022 9:00

Nature of Proceedings: Petition: Probate Will & Letters Testamentary

Probate Notes:

 

The following must be submitted:

 

1) Proof of Publication.  Jurisdiction of the Probate Court is obtained by publication in accordance with Probate Code section 8121.  (Prob. Code, § 8003(b).)  No proof of publication was filed.  Publication requires the notice to be published in newspaper adjudicated as a newspaper of general circulation in the city of decedent’s residence. (Prob. Code, §§ 8121, 7122.)

 

2) Trust Instrument.  The Petition and/or accompanying documents reveal the existence of a trust. A copy of the trust, and all accompanying amendments, must be submitted for review, to ensure compliance with the Decedent’s testamentary intent and notice to individuals who might otherwise not be given notice. (Local Rule, 1791(c).)

 

3) Supplement to the Petition.  The following allegations must be made without creating ambiguity, but were left blank or improperly alleged and must be corrected by supplement:

 

-       Paragraph 8 – A supplement to the petition listing all known trust beneficiaries and trustees must be submitted. Paragraph 8 of the petition specifically requires listing “all beneficiaries of a trust.”  The Court has discretion to require service to these heirs pursuant to Probate Code section 1202.

 

4) Proposed Order (Form DE-140).  A proposed order must be submitted with relief that matches that requested in the petition.  No such document was filed with the court.

 

5) Proposed Letters (Form DE-150).  Proposed letters must be submitted with relief that matches that requested in the petition.  No such document was filed with the court.

 

If the documents curing these deficiencies are not processed by 8:00 a.m. on June 6, 2022, it is recommended that the matter be continued to a date to be set by the Court at the hearing, unless the party appears and requests a different date, or submits a request for a different continuance date prior to the hearing. (Local Rule 1721(c)(2)(A-B).) If the matter is continued, documents must be submitted at least 10 days prior to the new hearing date to be considered.

 

Due to staffing limitations, processing times may be delayed. To assist in processing, attorneys and parties should include the next court date in the “Filing Description” field provided by the electronic service provider. That field is also used for further descriptions of the document being e-filed, so be sure to put the calendar date FIRST in the field – BEFORE any further description of the document being e-filed (e.g.: 06/28/16 For XYZ).

Estate of Wilma F Martin
Case No: 22PR00207
Hearing Date: Tue Jun 07, 2022 9:00

Nature of Proceedings: Petition: Probate Will & Letters Testamentary

Probate Notes:

 

The following must be submitted:

 

1) Proof of Publication. Jurisdiction of the Probate Court is obtained by publication in accordance with Probate Code section 8121. (Prob. Code, § 8003(b).) No proof of publication was filed. Publication requires the notice to be published in newspaper adjudicated as a newspaper of general circulation in the city of decedent’s residence. (Prob. Code, §§ 8121, 7122.) Santa Barbara Independent has not been adjudicated a newspaper of general circulation in the city of Lompoc, where Decedent was a resident. A declaration of substantial compliance is required. (Prob. Code, § 8122.)

 

2) Proof of Service of Notice of Hearing (Form DE-121). Notice must be given 15 days prior to hearing, served on all known heirs and devisees, as well as on the Personal Representative (if not the petitioner) and special notice requestors. (Prob. Code, §§ 8100 & 8110.) Notice must be sent to the person, not the person’s representative. (§1220.) Although the Proof of Service on file is sufficient for the two heirs listed in the petition, any trust beneficiaries not listed in the petition must also be served.

 

3) Trust Instrument. The Petition and/or accompanying documents reveal the existence of a trust. A copy of the trust, and all accompanying amendments, must be submitted for review, to ensure compliance with the Decedent’s testamentary intent and notice to individuals who might otherwise not be given notice. (Local Rule, 1791(c).)

 

4) Supplement to the Petition. The following allegations must be made without creating ambiguity, but were left blank or improperly alleged and must be corrected by supplement:

 

-       Paragraph 8 – A supplement to the petition listing all known heirs must be provided, even if those heirs are deceased, including “all beneficiaries of a trust named in decedent’s will.” (Pet. at ¶8.) The Court has discretion to require service to trust beneficiaries pursuant to Probate Code section 1202.

 

If the documents curing these deficiencies are not processed by 8:00 a.m. on June 6, 2022, it is recommended that the matter be continued to a date to be set by the Court at the hearing, unless the party appears and requests a different date, or submits a request for a different continuance date prior to the hearing. (Local Rule 1721(c)(2)(A-B).) If the matter is continued, documents must be submitted at least 10 days prior to the new hearing date to be considered.

Due to staffing limitations, processing times may be delayed. To assist in processing, attorneys and parties should include the next court date in the “Filing Description” field provided by the electronic service provider. That field is also used for further descriptions of the document being e-filed, so be sure to put the calendar date FIRST in the field – BEFORE any further description of the document being e-filed (e.g.: 06/28/16 For XYZ).

Probate Notes:

 

Court records show that an Accounting is due. [See Prob. C. § 2620] The Accounting and Notice of Hearing must be filed within 30 days of the date of the notice sent to you, or 45 days if the guardian or conservator is a public agency. [Prob. C. § 2620.2(a)] Failure to file the accounting within the time specified constitutes a contempt of the authority of the court and will result in sanctions as described in Prob. C. § 2620.2.

 

If the estate qualifies, the guardian or conservator may request an order dispensing with accountings pursuant to Prob. C. § 2628. This may often be accomplished by submission of a declaration (Judicial Council Form MC-030) ex parte.
