title: Tentative Ruling
body:
Tentative Ruling

Judge Colleen Sterne
Department 5 SB-Anacapa
1100 Anacapa Street P.O. Box 21107 Santa Barbara, CA 93121-1107

CIVIL LAW & MOTION

People ex rel. Calonne v. Pini
Case No: 17CV00718
Hearing Date: Fri Jun 03, 2022 9:00

Nature of Proceedings: Motion for Summary Adjudication

 

 

People ex rel. Calonne v. Pini (Judge Sterne)

Case No. 17CV00718

           

Hearing Date: June 3, 2022                                                    

 

 

HEARING:              Motion of City of Santa Barbara for Summary Adjudication

                                   

 

ATTORNEYS:        For Plaintiff People of the State of California ex rel. Ariel Pierre Calonne: Ariel Pierre Calonne, John S. Doimas, Office of the City Attorney; Matthew R. Silver, Rene L. Farjeat, Silver & Wright LLP

                                    For Defendants Dario L. Pini, D.L.P. Properties, Dario L. Pini, trustee of the Dario L. Pini Trust dated March 2, 2015, Nonnie Investments, LLC, 104 Las Aguajes, LLC, Alamar II, LLC, and Alamar III, LLC: Paul R. Burns, Solange D. Sanhueza, Law Offices of Paul R. Burns, P.C.

                                    For Defendant JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A.: John M. Sorich, Matthew S. Henderson, Parker Ibrahim & Berg LLP

                                    For Defendant Colony American Finance 2015-1 LTD: David M. Hershorin, Sarah C. Denis, Hershorin & Henry, LLP

                                

 

TENTATIVE RULING:

 

The motion of plaintiff People of the State of California etc. for summary adjudication is denied in its entirety.

 

 

Background:

 

On February 16, 2017, plaintiff People of the State of California ex rel. Calonne (City) filed the original complaint in the lead case (case No. 17CV00718). Case No. 17CV00718 asserts a single cause of action under the Business and Professions Code section 17200 et seq. (UCL). This action alleges violations of the Health and Safety Code, California Building Standards Code, California Fire Code, California Building Code, California Residential Code, California Electrical Code, California Plumbing Code, the International Property Maintenance Code, and the Santa Barbara Municipal Code as to 12 properties owned by defendants in Santa Barbara located at: (1) 26 Chapala Street; (2) 102 West Cabrillo Boulevard; (3) 104 Los Aguajes Avenue; (4) 313 West Arrellaga Street; (5) 318 West Valerio Street; (6) 320 West Valerio Street; (7) 320 West Mission Street; (8) 329 East Carrillo Street; (9) 615 San Pascual Street; (10) 626-630 West Cota Street; (11) 1816 State Street; and (12) 1335 Mission Ridge Road. (Complaint, ¶¶ 20, 23.) The complaint prays for an injunction to restrain defendants from violating the UCL, an injunction to abate and remediate the properties, appointment of a receiver to assume control of the properties and to abate and remediate unlawful conditions, for civil penalties, and for costs and attorney fees.

 

On June 5, 2017, defendants Dario L. Pini, D.L.P. Properties, Dario L. Pini, as trustee of the Dario L. Pini Trust dated March 2, 2015, Nonnie Investments, LLC, 104 Las Aguajes, LLC, Alamar II, LLC, and Alamar III, LLC (collectively, the Pini Defendants) filed their answer to the complaint in case No. 17CV00718 generally denying the allegations thereof and asserting five affirmative defenses.

 

On June 21, 2017, the City filed its original complaint in case No. 17CV02720. The complaint in case No. 17CV02720 asserts four causes of action: (1) violations of State Housing Law for a Receivership (Health & Saf. Code, § 17980 et seq.); (2) public nuisance (Civ. Code, §§ 731, 3479, 3480, 3491); (3) public nuisance per se (Santa Barbara Municipal Code and adopted codes); and (4) civil penalties (Santa Barbara Municipal Code, § 1.28.050).

 

On July 10, 2017, the court ordered case No. 17CV02720 consolidated with case No. 17CV00718.

 

On September 29, 2017, the Pini Defendants filed their verified answer to the complaint in case No. 17CV02720 admitting and denying allegations thereof and asserting five affirmative defenses.

 

On November 7, 2017, the City filed its motion for appointment of a receiver and for other relief. The motion sought an order declaring that the conditions on the properties identified in the complaint in case No. 17CV02720 violate State and local laws and that such violations are so extensive and of such a nature that the health and safety of residents or the public are substantially endangered, appointing a receiver over these properties pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 17980.7, subdivision (c), and enjoining defendants in certain respects as to these properties.

 

On December 8, 2017, the court consolidated into the lead case additional cases No. 17CV05114, 17CV05159, 17CV05204, and 17CV05165. The court also set the City’s motion for trial on March 19, 2018.

 

On March 13, 2018, the court granted the City’s request for a witness exclusion order during trial. The court ordered that counsel meet and confer as to the order of witnesses. The court vacated the trial confirmation date of March 19 and set trial to commence on March 20. A court trial was held on the City’s motion to appoint a receiver on March 20, 21, and 27, 2018. Following closing arguments of counsel on March 27, the court took the matter under submission.

 

On April 18, 2018, the court entered its orders on the submitted matter. As set forth in the Master Order, the court granted the City’s motion and appointed a receiver pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 17980.7 (HSC receivership) as to the following property locations: (1) 318-320 West Valerio Street; (2) 626-630 West Cota Street; (3) 313 West Arrellaga Street; (4) 320 West Mission Street; (5) 615 San Pascual Street; (6) 329 East Carrillo Street; and (7) 104 Los Aguajes Avenue. The court denied the City’s motion pursuant to section 17980.7 as to the property located at 26 Chapala Street, but granted the motion of the secured lender as to that property for appointment of a receiver. The court denied the motion as to the property located at 1816 State Street. The court vacated its submission as to the properties located at 102 West Cabrillo Boulevard and 1335 Mission Ridge Road pending further proceedings.

 

Since these orders were issued, the receiverships have been completed, the nuisance conditions on the properties ordered into receivership have been remediated, and possession of the properties ordered into receivership have been returned to the Pini Defendants.

 

On November 17, 2021, the City filed its motion for summary adjudication of its causes of action. The City argues that the court’s adjudication of City’s application for orders for receiverships entitles it to summary adjudication. (Note: The City’s separate statement appears to repeat separate statement facts under different headings using different numbers for the same separate statement facts. The preferred practice is to use the same separate statement fact number for a unique fact wherever it appears in a separate statement. This practice facilitates the court’s review of separate statement facts by making repeated review of the same (but differently numbered) fact unnecessary.)

 

The Pini Defendants oppose the motion. The Pini Defendants argue that the motion is procedurally defective in that it fails to adjudicate any complete cause of action and improperly seeks to partially adjudicate the City’s causes of action. In supplemental opposition, the Pini Defendants also argue that the motion is substantively insufficient.

 

The motion is also opposed by Colony American Finance 2015-1 LTD (Colony) and by JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. (Chase) (collectively, Banks).) The Banks argue that, as to them, the motion is both procedurally and substantively insufficient.

 

Analysis:

 

“A party may move for summary adjudication as to one or more causes of action within an action, one or more affirmative defenses, one or more claims for damages, or one or more issues of duty, if the party contends that the cause of action has no merit, that there is no affirmative defense to the cause of action, that there is no merit to an affirmative defense as to any cause of action, that there is no merit to a claim for damages, as specified in Section 3294 of the Civil Code, or that one or more defendants either owed or did not owe a duty to the plaintiff or plaintiffs. A motion for summary adjudication shall be granted only if it completely disposes of a cause of action, an affirmative defense, a claim for damages, or an issue of duty.” (Code Civ. Proc., § 437c, subd. (f)(1).)

 

“A plaintiff … has met his or her burden of showing that there is no defense to a cause of action if that party has proved each element of the cause of action entitling the party to judgment on the cause of action. Once the plaintiff … has met that burden, the burden shifts to the defendant … to show that a triable issue of one or more material facts exists as to the cause of action or a defense thereto. The defendant … shall not rely upon the allegations or denials of its pleadings to show that a triable issue of material fact exists but, instead, shall set forth the specific facts showing that a triable issue of material fact exists as to the cause of action or a defense thereto.” (Code Civ. Proc., § 437c, subd. (p)(1).)

 

(1)       Requests for Judicial Notice

 

In support of its motion for summary adjudication, the City requests that the court take judicial notice of: (City Exhibits, exhibit A) Order After Hearing (Master Order) filed April 18, 2018, filed in this action; (exhibit B)Order After Hearing (Receivership Order 1: 318-320 W. Valerio St.) filed April 18, 2018; (exhibit C) Order After Hearing (Receivership Order 2: 626-630 W. Cota St.) filed April 18, 2018; (exhibit D) Order After Hearing (Receivership Order 3: 313 W. Arrellaga St.) filed April 18, 2018; (exhibit E) Order After Hearing (Receivership Order 4: 320 W. Mission St.) filed April 18, 2018; (exhibit F) Order After Hearing (Receivership Order 5: 615 San Pascual St.) filed April 18, 2018; (exhibit G) Order After Hearing (Receivership Order 6: 229 E. Carrillo St.) filed April 18, 2018; (exhibit H) Order After Hearing (Receivership Order 7: 104 Los Aguajes Ave.) filed April 18, 2018; (exhibit I) Stipulation for Judgment With [Proposed] Judgment And Order filed June 28, 2013, in People etc., et al., v. Pini, et al., Santa Barbara County Superior Court case No. 141623; (exhibit J) Judgment And Order filed June 28, 2013, in case No. 141623; (exhibit K) Stipulation to Amend Judgment filed August 8, 2013, in case No. 141623; and (exhibit L)Excerpts of Receiver’s Progress Report; Statement Of Account for the Month of June 2018 (Receivership Order 2; 626-630 W. Cota St.) filed on July 23, 2018, pages 1-13. The court grants these requests for judicial notice as court records. (See Evid. Code, § 452, subd. (d)(1).)

 

In opposition to the motion, the Pini Defendants request that the court take judicial notice of: (Pini Defendants’ Request for Judicial Notice, exhibit A) the City’s complaint in case No. 17CV02720; (exhibit B) Order After Hearing (Master Order) filed April 18, 2018, filed in this action; and (exhibit C) the City’s complaint in case No. 17CV00718. The court grants these requests for judicial notice as court records. (See Evid. Code, § 452, subd. (d)(1).)

 

In supplemental opposition, the Pini Defendants request that the court take judicial notice of: (Pini Defendants’ Supplemental Request for Judicial Notice, exhibit A) the City’s complaint in case No. 17CV00718; (exhibit B) the City’s complaint in case No. 17CV02720; (exhibit C) the City’s Notice and Order to Repair and Abate, dated February 14, 2017, as to the property located at 329 E. Carrillo Street; (exhibit D) the court’s minute order, dated March 19, 2021, filed in this action; and (exhibit E) the court’s written order, filed April 2, 2021, filed in this action. The requests as to exhibits A, B, D, and E are granted as court records. (See Evid. Code, § 452, subd. (d)(1).) (The court notes that it is unnecessary for a responding party to separately request judicial notice where the same document is the subject of the moving party’s request. It is also unnecessary to repeat a request for judicial notice in supplemental papers filed in the same motion to which judicial notice has already been requested.) The requests as to exhibit C is granted as an official act of a government agency. (See Evid. Code, § 452, subd. (c).) As with court records, judicial notice does not extend to the truth of factual matters set forth in such records. (Arce v. Kaiser Foundation Health Plan, Inc. (2010) 181 Cal.App.4th 471, 484.)

 

(2)       Motion for Summary Adjudication

 

The Pini Defendants argue that the motion is procedurally improper because the motion does not dispose of a single cause of action. The complaint in case No. 17CV00718 does not assert separately labeled causes of action, but is instead asserted as a single cause of action under the UCL based upon multiple alleged examples of violations for each of the 12 properties identified in the complaint. (17CV00718 Complaint, ¶¶ 23, 27.) Similarly, the complaint in case No. 17CV02720 sets forth four causes of action based upon multiple alleged violations for each of the 12 properties identified in the complaint. (17CV02720 Complaint, ¶¶ 114, 122, 135.) None of the causes of action are pleaded as separate causes of action applying to a specific property as opposed to all of the properties together. In ruling on the receivership motion, the court ordered a receivership as to some of the properties but denied the motion for a receivership as to other properties. Because the City’s motion for summary adjudication is based only upon those properties for which the City was successful in obtaining a receivership under Health and Safety Code section 17980.7, and the City was not successful in obtaining a receivership as to all properties referenced in each of the pleaded causes of action, the Pini Defendants argue that the City’s motion does not comply with section 437c, subdivision (f)(1) limiting summary adjudication to disposing of complete causes of action.

 

In response to this argument, the City argues that the rule of subdivision (f)(1) is not violated where there are separate and distinct wrongful acts that could be addressed independently as a separate cause of action, citing Lilienthal & Fowler v. Superior Court (1993) 12 Cal.App.4th 1848 (Lilienthal) and Edward Fineman Co. v. Superior Court (1998) 66 Cal.App.4th 1110 (Fineman).

 

In Lilienthal, the case arose out of legal services that the defendant law firm and attorneys rendered at different times to the plaintiff clients on two separate and distinct matters, both of which plaintiffs alleged constituted legal malpractice. (Lilienthal, supra, 12 Cal.App.4th at p. 1850.) The plaintiffs’ complaint alleged two causes of action, for breach of contract and for negligence, each cause of action asserting the malpractice in both matters as the basis for the cause of action. (Ibid.) The defendants filed a motion for summary adjudication that, among other things, asserted that the claim based on one of the two separate matters was barred by the statute of limitations. (Ibid.) The trial court denied the motion on the basis of subdivision (f)’s limitation because disposition of the defendants’ motion would not have resolved an entire cause of action where each cause of action included a claim also based upon the other matter (not subject to the motion for summary adjudication).

 

On writ review, the Lilienthal court considered the motion for summary adjudication as within the limitations of subdivision (f): “In the instant case, plaintiffs seek to recover damages based on two separate and distinct obligations. Each obligation creates a separate and distinct claim. … There is no dispute that the two matters have no relation to each other and involve legal services performed at different times, with different and distinct obligations, and distinct and separate alleged damages. Under California law, the allegations relating to the [two] matters involve two separate and distinct causes of action regardless of how pled in the complaint.” (Lilienthal, supra, 12 Cal.App.4th at p. 1854.) “The policy behind motions for summary judgment and summary adjudication is to ‘promote and protect the administration of justice, and to expedite litigation by the elimination of needless trials.’ [Citation.] … ‘[The] statement and the wording of subdivision (f) show clearly that the Legislature wished to narrow summary adjudication from its broad focus on “issues” (sometimes interpreted to mean only asserted “facts”) to a more limited focus on causes of action, affirmative defenses, claims for punitive damages, and claims that defendants did not owe plaintiffs a duty.’ [Citation.]” (Ibid.) “In our judgment the clearly articulated legislative intent of section 437c, subdivision (f), is effectuated by applying the section in a manner which would provide for the determination on the merits of summary adjudication motions involving separate and distinct wrongful acts which are combined in the same cause of action. To rule otherwise would defeat the time and cost saving purposes of the amendment and allow a cause of action in its entirety to proceed to trial even where, as here, a separate and distinct alleged obligation or claim may be summarily defeated by summary adjudication.” (Id. at pp. 1854–1855.)

 

In Fineman, the plaintiff filed a complaint against its bank asserting causes of action for breach of contract, negligence, and damages under Uniform Commercial Code section 4103. (Fineman, supra, 66 Cal.App.4th at p. 1115.) Each of these causes of action were based upon allegations that the bank improperly paid 83 checks between January 1, 1991, and June 1, 1996. (Ibid.) The bank moved for summary adjudication with respect to 23 of the checks between January 1, 1991, and January 1, 1993, on the grounds of the statute of limitations. (Ibid.) The trial court granted the motion. (Ibid.)

 

On writ review, the Fineman court first addressed the plaintiff’s argument that summary adjudication was improper under subdivision (f) because the motion did not dispose of a complete cause of action. (Fineman, supra, 66 Cal.App.4th at p. 1116.) The court held that “each altered, forged, or unauthorized check stands on its own as a separate claim, independently subject to such affirmative defenses as may be applicable. In other words, notwithstanding the aggregation of the 23 1991–1993 checks, each constitutes a separate cause of action susceptible to a complete disposition if barred by affirmative defenses asserted by [the bank].” (Id. at p. 1118.) Quoting and applying the above language from Lilienthal as to the purpose of summary adjudication, the Fineman court determined that summary adjudication was procedurally proper as to each check separately, notwithstanding that the plaintiff had aggregated its claims into single causes of action in its complaint. (Ibid.)

 

The procedural situation here is both similar to and different from Lilienthal and Fineman. Interestingly, in both Lilienthal and Fineman the moving party was a defendant. In those cases, summary adjudication was permitted notwithstanding the plaintiff’s failure to state distinct claims as separate causes of action. As Lilienthal noted, after the amendment of the demurrer statute in 1973 to abolish the ground for demurrer that each cause of action is not separately stated, “defendants have no remedy to compel plaintiffs to separately plead distinct causes of action, unless brought under the ground of uncertainty.” (Lilienthal, supra, 12 Cal.App.4th at p. 1855, fn. 4.) If the claims in Lilienthal or Fineman had been separately designated as a unique causes of action by the plaintiff, there would have been no issue among the parties that summary adjudication of each cause of action would have been procedurally proper. Because the plaintiffs in those cases had aggregated multiple legally distinct claims into single causes of action, the more basic question answered by those decisions was whether the procedural right to summary adjudication is determined by the plaintiff’s own characterization of the plaintiff’s claims (so as effectively to insulate defective, independent claims from summary adjudication) or is determined by looking through plaintiff’s characterization to what are underlying “causes of action” within the meaning of subdivision (f). Thus, the interpretation of subdivision (f) in Lilienthal and Fineman protects a defendant’s right to summary adjudication of defective, independent claims as against a plaintiff’s faulty aggregate pleading.

 

In the present context, the moving party is the plaintiff—indeed, the plaintiff who wrote the pleadings as containing aggregated “causes of action” rather than separately identified causes of action based upon each independent claim (see Cal. Rules of Court, rule 2.112). Had the City written its pleadings so that its “causes of action” aligned with the causes of action it now seeks to summarily adjudicate, either the Pini Defendants’ argument would disappear or would have to change so as to argue that individually asserted claims are not each a “cause of action” within the meaning of subdivision (f) and must be aggregated. “The primary function of a pleading is to give the other party notice so that it may prepare its case [citation] ….” (Harris v. City of Santa Monica (2013) 56 Cal.4th 203, 240.) “By framing and limiting the issues, the complaint limits the bases upon which a plaintiff may seek to impose liability on a defendant.” (Centex Homes v. Superior Court (2013) 214 Cal.App.4th 1090, 1102.) Absent amendment, it is improper for City to argue that the defendants and the court should look beyond the City’s own actual pleadings and instead reconstitute the City’s pleading as an aggregation of claims that the City itself did not separately identify. Thus a sufficient resolution of this motion is to deny the motion on the grounds that, as the plaintiff has itself pleaded its claims and put defendant on notice as to what constitutes the causes of action upon which the City seeks to impose liability on the defendants, the motion does not resolve the entirety of any cause of action so pleaded. The motion is therefore improper under subdivision (f). This is a sufficient basis to deny the motion in its entirety.

 

The Banks make a related argument that the City’s notice of motion and separate statement do not comply with the California Rules of Court. “A motion must: [¶] … [¶] (2) Name the parties to whom it is addressed ….” (Cal. Rules of Court, rule 3.1112(d)(2).) The notice of motion does not expressly state the persons to whom it is addressed, merely stating that the City moves for an order “summarily adjudicating the following issues in the City’s favor.” (Notice, at p. 1.) The notice continues: “The City is entitled to summary adjudication on its causes of action for the following reasons ….” (Ibid.) The notice mentions “Defendants” once (Notice, at p. 1, ¶ 1) and the “Pini Defendants” once (Notice, at p. 1, ¶ 5), without defining either term. The City argues in reply that the notice is sufficiently clear for the parties to understand the scope of the City’s motion as evidenced by the fact that the Pini Defendants and the Banks have filed oppositions to the motion.

 

The Banks also point out that the notice provisions regarding the separate statement are insufficient: “If summary adjudication is sought, whether separately or as an alternative to the motion for summary judgment, the specific cause of action, affirmative defense, claims for damages, or issues of duty must be stated specifically in the notice of motion and be repeated, verbatim, in the separate statement of undisputed material facts.” (Cal. Rules of Court, rule 3.1350(b).) A comparison between the Notice and the City’s separate statement shows that the text is not repeated verbatim and that the specific causes of action are not stated. The City responds that the text is sufficient and not confusing. City reasons, in part, that the descriptions are sufficient given City’s arguments, as discussed above, that summary adjudication of distinct, but unlabeled, causes of action is proper under Lilienthal and Fineman.

 

These two notice issues raised by the Banks run into the same problem of what is a “cause of action” under section 437c, subdivision (f). City argues as against the Pini Defendants that summary adjudication is proper for distinct “causes of action” which the City itself could easily have identified in the pleadings as distinct causes of action but did not. City argues here that it sufficiently identifies “causes of action” by the aggregate headings used in the complaint while at the same time seeking to adjudicate different, narrower “causes of action” particular to individual properties. This problem is compounded by the notice of motion not stating which adjudication is sought against which defendant where the City alleges ownership and security interests held differently as to different properties. (17CV02720 Complaint, ¶¶ 8-37.) By failing to identify specifically each “cause of action” for which it seeks summary adjudication and against whom it seeks summary adjudication, the City has failed to meet the notice requirements of rules 3.1112 and 3.1350. This is also a sufficient basis for denying the motion in its entirety.

 

Alternatively, even construing the pleadings as City argues as comprising distinct claims as to each property for which a receivership was ordered and the notice and separate statements procedurally sufficient, the motion would still be denied. The four causes of action for which summary adjudication is sought are for violation of the UCL, remedies under Health and Safety Code section 17980 et seq., nuisance, and nuisance per se. (See Motion, at pp. 9-17.) (Note: The City does not separately discuss the fourth cause of action of the 17CV02720 Complaint labelled as a cause of action for civil penalties under section 1.28.050 of the Santa Barbara Municipal Code. The failure to discuss this cause of action is a separate basis for denying summary adjudication as to that cause of action. (See Cal. Rules of Court, rule 3.1113(a).) In any event, summary adjudication as to that cause of action fails for the same reasons, discussed below, that the UCL cause of action fails.)

 

Chase argues that the nuisance and nuisance per se actions are moot; in their supplemental opposition, the Pini Defendants repeat this argument but stated more generally. “A case is considered moot when ‘the question addressed was at one time a live issue in the case,’ but has been deprived of life ‘because of events occurring after the judicial process was initiated.’ [Citation.] Because ‘ “the duty of ... every ... judicial tribunal is to decide actual controversies by a judgment which can be carried into effect, and not to give opinions upon moot questions or ... to declare principles or rules of law which cannot affect the matter in issue in the case before it[,] [i]t necessarily follows that when ... an event occurs which renders it impossible for [the] court, if it should decide the case in favor of plaintiff, to grant him any effectual relief whatever, the court will not proceed to formal judgment....” [Citation.]’ [Citation.] The pivotal question in determining if a case is moot is therefore whether the court can grant the plaintiff any effectual relief. [Citations.] If events have made such relief impracticable, the controversy has become ‘overripe’ and is therefore moot. [Citations.]” (Wilson & Wilson v. City Council of Redwood City (2011) 191 Cal.App.4th 1559, 1574.)

 

In support of its argument for mootness of these two causes of action, Chase points to evidence that the nuisance conditions alleged in the complaints as to the receivership properties have now been fully abated. (Henderson decl., ¶¶ 12-16 & exhibits 3, 4.) More generally, the City’s own evidence is that the “violations of State and local law previously identified by the City in its prior notices have been corrected and abated.” (Dunn decl., ¶ 17.) Because the nuisance conditions have been abated, there is no remaining remedy sought by the City that the court would provide as to these causes of action. The controversy is therefore moot.

 

In reply, the City asserts that it is entitled to summary adjudication even though the nuisance has been abated prior to trial, citing City of Norco v. Mugar (2020) 59 Cal.App.5th 786 (Norco). In Norco, the plaintiff city issued notices ordering the defendant to abate substandard conditions at defendant’s property. (Id. at p. 790.) Even after extending the time to abate the nuisance, the defendant failed to comply and conditions got worse. (Ibid.) The city then filed “both a ‘Petition for Appointment of Receiver, Injunctive and Other Relief Pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 17980.7, et seq.’ …, and a motion for appointment of a receiver and preliminary injunction.” (Id. at pp. 790–791.) The trial court granted the city’s motion, appointed a receiver and ordered a preliminary injunction. (Id. at p. 791.) The order was subject to a provision that the defendant was permitted to continue his voluntary abatement measures until the receiver accepted his appointment. (Ibid.) After the receiver accepted his appointment, the parties stipulated that the receivership would be held in abeyance while the defendant corrected the violations, subject to certain qualifications. (Ibid.) The corrections were timely made except for one remaining issue concerning a laundry room. (Id. at p. 792.) A lengthy dispute ensued regarding repairs to the laundry room. (Ibid.) About a year later, the defendant completed the repairs to the laundry room and property passed its final inspection. (Ibid.) At the city’s request, the court vacated the order appointing the receiver on the ground that all of the nuisance issues had been resolved. (Ibid.) As a result, the matter was dismissed. (Id. at p. 789.) The city then brought a motion to be declared the prevailing party in the litigation and for attorney fees and costs, which the trial court granted. (Id. at p. 792.)

 

On appeal in Norco, the defendant made a number of constitutional arguments which were rejected on their merits. (Norco, supra, 59 Cal.App.5th at pp. 793-799.) The defendant also argued that the trial court erred in finding that the city was the prevailing party. (Id. at p. 799.) The Norco court first rejected the city’s argument that it was unnecessary to reach the issue of whether the city was the prevailing party because attorney fees and costs were proper as reasonable costs of enforcement under Health and Safety Code section 17980.7, subdivision (d)(1). (Ibid.) The court held that the attorney fee provision of subdivision (c)(11) is the applicable statute where a receiver was appointed under subdivision (c). (Id. at pp. 799-800.)

 

“Health and Safety Code section 17980.7, subdivision (c)(11) provides: ‘The prevailing party in an action pursuant to this section shall be entitled to reasonable attorney's fees and court costs as may be fixed by the court.’ This statute does not define the term ‘prevailing party,’ so the trial court should ‘analyze[ ] which party had prevailed on a practical level.’ [Citation.] Here, the trial court did so using the ‘catalyst theory.’ Courts applying this theory look to the practical impact of litigation on the public interest to determine whether the plaintiff may be awarded attorney fees. [Citation.] ‘Under the catalyst theory, attorney fees may be awarded even when litigation does not result in a judicial resolution if the defendant changes its behavior substantially because of, and in the manner sought by, the litigation.’ [Citation.]” (Norco, supra, 59 Cal.App.5th at p. 800.) The Norco court held that the trial court reasonably determined that the defendant would not have complied with the city’s abatement order without the appointment of a receiver. (Ibid.)

 

The defendant in Norco argued that the city’s specific legal action was unsuccessful. (Norco, supra, 59 Cal.App.5th at p. 800.) The Norco court disagreed, holding that the city’s litigation objective was to abate a public nuisance and that objective was achieved by the litigation even though the work was actually accomplished by the defendant. (Id. at pp. 800-801.) The Norco court thus affirmed the judgment. (Id. at p. 802.)

 

As the above discussion of Norco demonstrates, Norco does not provide any support for, nor does it even mention, the availability of summary adjudication. The procedural posture of Norco, on the contrary, demonstrates the mootness point here involving claims of nuisance and nuisance per se. “It is well settled that statutory costs and attorney fees are incident to the judgment ….” (Berti v. Santa Barbara Beach Properties (2006) 145 Cal.App.4th 70, 75.) In Norco, the determination and award of attorney fees and costs was made as an incident to a judgment of dismissal. The fact that the case was dismissed because the nuisance had been abated prior to trial is why the catalyst theory was applied rather than applying the traditional test for the prevailing party. (See Graham v. DaimlerChrysler Corp. (2004) 34 Cal.4th 553, 565–566 [under a catalyst theory, ‘an attorney fee award may be justified even when plaintiff’s legal action does not result in a favorable final judgment.’].)

 

For purposes of this discussion, Norco is consistent with dismissing a nuisance claim as moot where the nuisance is abated. The City does not substantively argue that there is any relief that the court would or could award specific to the nuisance causes of action now that the nuisance conditions have been abated. The City does not claim damages to itself from the past existence of the nuisance (see Civ. Code, § 3484; County of Santa Clara v. Atlantic Richfield Co. (2006) 137 Cal.App.4th 292, 310 [California nuisance law “does not grant a damage remedy in actions brought on behalf of the People to abate a public nuisance”]) and has no apparent basis for an injunction to prohibit what has already been remediated (see County of Santa Clara, supra, 137 Cal.App.4th at p. 310 [“An abatement of a nuisance is accomplished by a court of equity by means of an injunction proper and suitable to the facts of each case.”]). Thus, one characterization of the City’s own evidence in support of this motion is that it demonstrates the lack of entitlement to summary adjudication on the grounds of mootness. So characterized, the City fails to meet its initial burden on the motion. Alternatively, the City’s own evidence can be characterized as susceptible to competing inferences as to whether there is a complete defense on the grounds of mootness, thus demonstrating the existence of triable issues of fact. (See Code Civ. Proc., § 437c, subd. (c) [“summary judgment shall not be granted by the court based on inferences reasonably deducible from the evidence if contradicted by other inferences or evidence that raise a triable issue as to any material fact”].) In either case, the court denies the motion for summary adjudication as to causes of action for nuisance and for nuisance per se on this alternative ground.

 

Mootness is not an issue in this motion as to the two other “causes of action” for which the City seeks summary adjudication. In the UCL action, the City seeks civil penalties. (See Bus. & Prof. Code, § 17206; 17CV00718 Complaint, prayer, ¶¶ 5, 6.) In the Health and Safety Code cause of action (HSC action), among other things, the City seeks enforcement costs. (See Health & Saf. Code, § 17980.7, subd. (d); 17CV02720 Complaint, prayer, ¶¶ 8, 9.)

 

Again assuming the City’s characterization of the “cause of action,” the City seeks summary adjudication of both the UCL action and the HSC action on the grounds that the court has previously adjudicated the issue of a receivership in the City’s favor. The Pini Defendants argue that the appointment of a receiver is a provisional remedy which has no conclusive effect upon the merits. The Banks argue that while the City makes this argument, it provides no legal authority to support the contention that summary adjudication is proper. The Banks point out that the doctrines of law of the case and issue preclusion (collateral estoppel) do not apply. In reply, the City continues to assert that the court’s rulings appointing the receiverships constitute final determinations which resolve the merits, but still without providing any legal framework.

 

The Pini Defendants focus on the traditional role of a receivership: “The appointment of a receiver is an equitable remedy, and there is no such thing as an action brought for the mere appointment of a receiver.” (In re Stein (1936) 14 Cal.App.2d 303, 305.) “A receivership is designed to be merely a provisional remedy. It preserves the status quo of property while litigation is pending. ‘[T]he “appointment of a receiver in equity is not a substantive right; rather, it is an ancillary remedy which does not affect the ultimate outcome of the action.” [Citations.]’ [Citation.]” (Southern California Sunbelt Developers, Inc. v. Banyan Limited Partnership (2017) 8 Cal.App.5th 910, 925.) The Pini Defendants thus analogize the receivership order to a preliminary injunction.

 

“[A]n order granting or denying interlocutory relief reflects nothing more than the superior court’s evaluation of the controversy on the record before it at the time of its ruling; it is not an adjudication of the ultimate merits of the dispute.” (People ex rel. Gallo v. Acuna (1997) 14 Cal.4th 1090, 1109, italics omitted.) “If a lawsuit seeks a preliminary and a permanent injunction, … the order for a preliminary injunction does not determine the ultimate right to a permanent injunction—i.e., a preliminary injunction is not a determination on the merits—unless the question before the trial court is one of law alone that can be resolved without resort to extrinsic or additional evidence.” (Yee v. American National Ins. Co. (2015) 235 Cal.App.4th 453, 457–458.)

 

The City, on the other hand, repeatedly emphasizes the court’s rulings on the receivership as the court’s “final rulings.” (E.g., Motion, at pp. 1-2.) The rulings are “final,” the City points out because the orders “were not appealed and are now final.” (Motion, at p. 2.) The City apparently refers to the fact that orders appointing a receiver are separately appealable. (Code Civ. Proc., § 904.1, subd. (a)(7).) But finality in this sense only means that the determination to appoint a receiver cannot be directly attacked as legally improper. Orders granting or denying an injunction are also appealable. (Code Civ. Proc., § 904.1, subd. (a)(6).) If not appealed an order granting an injunction is also final in that same sense, but, as noted above, finality of the order does not mean that an order for an injunction is a determination of the merits. And, notwithstanding finality, the court retains the power and authority to modify an injunction. (Code Civ. Proc., § 533; City of San Marcos v. Coast Waste Management, Inc. (1996) 47 Cal.App.4th 320, 328.)

 

In the absence of a legal framework articulated by the City, Chase supposes that the City’s emphasis on finality is intended to invoke either the doctrine of law of the case or collateral estoppel (issue preclusion). Chase then correctly notes that neither doctrine is applicable. “ ‘The doctrine that a previous ruling has become law of the case has no application except as to the decisions of appellate Courts.’ [Citations.]” (Provience v. Valley Clerks Trust Fund (1984) 163 Cal.App.3d 249, 256.) There is no decision by an appellate court here.

 

“Issue preclusion prohibits the relitigation of issues argued and decided in a previous case, even if the second suit raises different causes of action.” (DKN Holdings LLC v. Faerber (2015) 61 Cal.4th 813, 824.) “In summary, issue preclusion [also known as collateral estoppel] applies: (1) after final adjudication (2) of an identical issue (3) actually litigated and necessarily decided in the first suit and (4) asserted against one who was a party in the first suit or one in privity with that party.” (Id. at p. 825.) There are missing elements here. First, “finality for purposes of appellate review is not the same as finality for purposes of res judicata.” (George Arakelian Farms, Inc. v. Agricultural Labor Relations Bd. (1989) 49 Cal.3d 1279, 1290–1291.) To the extent that the receivership order is like a preliminary injunction, as argued above, finality for issue preclusion purposes is missing. Second, there is no previous case. Third, there is a difference between what was necessarily decided by the receivership orders and what is to be decided in resolving this motion for summary adjudication.

 

This difference in issues decided by the order and issues to be decided in this motion (and later at trial) raises the problem of characterizing the legal effect of the proceedings that led to the receivership orders. The receivership orders at issue (as limited by the City’s motion) are those orders issued pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 17980.7.

 

“If the owner fails to comply within a reasonable time with the terms of the order or notice issued pursuant to Section 17980.6, the following provisions shall apply: [¶] … [¶] (c) The enforcement agency … may seek and the court may order, the appointment of a receiver for the substandard building pursuant to this subdivision.” (Health & Saf. Code, § 17980.7, subd. (c).) (Note: Since the receivership orders were issued in April 2018, section 17980.6 has been amended in certain limited aspects that are not material to the discussion here. (See Stats. 2019, ch. 620, § 4.).)

 

“If any building is maintained in a manner that violates any provisions of this part, the building standards published in the State Building Standards Code relating to the provisions of this part, any other rule or regulation adopted pursuant to the provisions of this part, or any provision in a local ordinance that is similar to a provision in this part, and the violations are so extensive and of such a nature that the health and safety of residents or the public is substantially endangered, the enforcement agency may issue an order or notice to repair or abate pursuant to this part.” (Health & Saf. Code, § 17980.6

 

The court’s April 18, 2018, orders specific to the properties here at issue made the following findings (using the order for the property located at 318-320 W. Valerio as an exemplar):

 

“4.       The Property is substandard, constitutes a public nuisance, and is being maintained in a manner that violates state and local laws.

“5.       The violations of law as to the conditions of the building located at the Property are soextensive and of such a nature that the health and safety of residents or the public is substantiallyendangered within the meaning of Health and Safety Code section 17980.6.

“6.       City, as the enforcement agency, properly issued defendants Notices and Orders to Repairor Abate (N&Os) the building violations and nuisance conditions on the Property pursuant to section17980.6.

“7.       The City afforded defendants a reasonable time to correct the violations and abatenuisance conditions on the Property pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 17980, subdivision (a),and 17980.7.

“8.       Defendants failed to comply with the N&O and bring the Property into full compliancewith the N&Os and all applicable laws within a reasonable time.

“9.       The City sufficiently provided defendants with at least three days’ advance notice of theﬁling of the Veriﬁed Complaint for Nuisance Abatement and Receivership (Complaint) before theComplaint was ﬁled on June 21, 2017 in accordance with Health and Safety Code section 17980.7,subdivision (c).

“10.     Defendants, and all recorded legal interest holders, were properly served with theSummons and Complaint.

“11.     The nuisance conditions on the Property have been ongoing and will likely persist unlessthis Court appoints a receiver to correct the violations and abate the nuisance conditions on the Property.

“12.     Pursuant to Health and Safety Code section 17980.7, subdivision (c), and Code of CivilProcedure section 564, subdivision (b)(9), and the Court’s inherent equitable powers, this Court has theauthority to, and hereby does, appoint a receiver to correct the violations and abate the nuisanceconditions on the Property.” (Order After Hearing, Receivership Order 1, filed Apr. 18, 2018, at pp. 2-3.)

 

As required by sections 17980.6 and 17980.7, the court made affirmative findings that there were nuisance conditions at the property and that there had not been full compliance with the N&Os. However, the court did not decide, and did not impliedly decide, that any particular alleged violation did or did not exist or that the substandard, nuisance conditions were based upon any particular alleged violation or collection of violations. The court only decided that there were sufficient violations in quantity and quality to justify the findings required under sections 17980.6 and 17980.7 for the appointment of a receiver under section 17980.7, subdivision (c).

 

The requirements of such findings under sections 17980.6 and 17980.7 distinguishes the court’s rulings granting receiverships from preliminary injunctions and traditional receiverships. A preliminary injunction assesses and weighs the likelihood of success against the relative interim harms of granting or denying the injunction. (Smith v. Adventist Health System/West (2010) 182 Cal.App.4th 729, 749.) The ruling on the HSC receiverships makes the affirmative determination of the present existence of nuisance conditions. “The appointment of a [traditional] receiver before judgment is ancillary to and in aid of the action. Its purpose is to preserve the property pending the litigation so that the relief awarded by the judgment, if any, may be effective.” (Steinberg v. Goldstein (1954) 129 Cal.App.2d 682, 686; see also Maggiora v. Palo Alto Inn, Inc. (1967) 249 Cal.App.2d 706, 712.) By contrast, the purpose of the HSC receivership is to abate the nuisance conditions and is the principal goal of the litigation under section 17980.7. The result of the HSC receivership is to permanently change the status quo. Thus, the analogy made by the Pini Defendants to a preliminary injunction or to a traditional receivership that the HSC receivership is a transitory provisional remedy is not apt.

 

This leaves the question of the significance of the court’s HSC receivership orders both for this motion and going forward. As the complete absence of citation to authority from any party suggests, there is no clear answer. The parties and the court conducted a full, adversarial evidentiary hearing which led to the factual and legal findings set forth in the HSC receivership orders. Given the nature of the HSC receiverships as intended to effect the ultimate purpose of litigation under sections 17980.6 and 17980.7, these orders are, in effect, the result of trial from a de facto bifurcation of the issues necessary for the disposition of the HSC receiverships. “Issues adjudicated in earlier phases of a bifurcated trial are binding in later phases of that trial and need not be relitigated.” (Arntz Contracting Co. v. St. Paul Fire & Marine Ins. Co. (1996) 47 Cal.App.4th 464, 487.)

 

Returning to the summary adjudication issues at hand, the differences between what was adjudicated in the HSC receiverships and what remains to be adjudicated in the HSC action and the UCL action again puts the City’s motion in conflict with the limitations of Code of Civil Procedure section 437c, subdivision (f). While monetary remedies are not elements of either of these causes of action and so summary adjudication is not dependent upon proof of those monetary remedies (People ex rel. Feuer v. Superior Court (Cahuenga’s the Spot) (2015) 234 Cal.App.4th 1360, 1383), the remedies remaining to be adjudicated depend upon determination of specific alleged violations, not upon the aggregate determination of the existence of conditions sufficient to order the properties into receivership. The City’s motion depends solely upon the determinations in the HSC orders. (City’s Separate Statement, facts 3-10, 33-40.) As discussed above, the HSC orders do not expressly or by implication determine any specific violation or violations exist. Each alleged violation of law is alleged as a separate violation of the UCL and as a basis for the remaining remedies of the HSC action. The HSC orders do not address or resolve any of these specific violations. The requested adjudications thus do not seek summary adjudication that would resolve the cause of action in any particular. In that respect the motion fails to meet its initial burden on summary adjudication. This is a separate, alternative basis for denying the motion as to these two “causes of action.”

 

Ultimately, as the discussion of Lilienthal explains, the purpose of summary adjudication is to dispose of a “cause of action” and avoid the practice of piecemeal adjudications of non-dispositive issues. The requested adjudication completely fails in this purpose. The most that summary adjudication would provide to the City is that the Pini Defendants have violated Health and Safety Code sections 17980.6 and 17980.7, and derivatively the UCL, generally, but that any further remedy depends upon a subsequent judicial determination of particular violations. Summary adjudication would result in the same procedural situation that already exists and would not remove any issue from a later trial or otherwise limit the scope of that trial.

 

For all of the foregoing reasons, the motion of City for summary adjudication will be denied.

title: Tentative Ruling
body:
Tentative Ruling

Judge Jed Beebe
Department 4 SM-Cook
312-C East Cook Street P.O. Box 5369 Santa Maria, CA 93456-5369

CONSERVATORSHIP

Conservatorship of Jaime Marcus Zendejas

Case No: 22PR00149
Hearing Date: Mon Jun 06, 2022 8:30

Nature of Proceedings: Petition for Appointment of Temporary Probate Conservator

Posted Probate Notes:

 

Appearances required. Petitioner must submit the following:

 

Proof of Personal Service of the Citation. The notice must be personally delivered to the proposed conservatee at least 5 court days before the hearing. A copy of the petition for temporary appointment shall be served with the notice of hearing. [Prob. C. § 2250(e)(2)]

 

Proof of Timely Mailed Service. Notice of the hearing shall be served five days prior to the hearing on the proposed conservatee’s spouse, parents, grandparents, children, grandchildren, and brothers and sisters (named in the Petition for Appointment of Conservator at ¶ 11). [Prob. C. § 2250(e)(2)]

 

Capacity Declaration. No order adjudging that conservatee lacks capacity to give informed consent to medical treatment may be granted unless supported by a declaration executed by a licensed physician or licensed psychologist supporting the request. [Prob. Code, § 1890(c).]

 

Proposed Letters. Letters of Temporary Guardianship or Conservatorship (GC-150) must be filed. A conservator with no letters has no authority to act.

 

The proposed temporary conservatee is expected to attend the hearing. (Prob. Code § 2250.4.)

title: Juror Instructions
body:
Juror Instructions

If you have received a Trial Jury Summons, examine the entire document carefully for the following information:

  • Summons Date
  • Jury Group Number
  • Juror ID Number
  • PIN Number
  • 24 hour information phone line

You will need to check the Superior Court's online jury portal or call the court's automated phone line at 855-955-1103 after 5:30 PM the evening prior to your summons date for the reporting instructions for your group. You will need to have your Juror ID number and PIN number available.

You must access the Superior Court's online jury portal at https://juryservice.sbcourts.org or call the court's automated phone line at 855-955-1103 to check for your status as directed during your on-call period to determine if you are required to report for service. Please have your summons handy when calling. You will need to enter your specific Juror ID Number and PIN Number to access your record. You will be placed on call for approximately five (5) court days. If directed to report for jury service you MUST bring your summons with you when you report and you MUST be on time. If you are not directed to report for service during your on-call period, you will be released as instructed on the recorded message or the court's website.

Find more information on the Judicial Council Web Site:

  • www.courts.ca.gov/juryservice.htm: A Guide to California Jury Service
  • What to Expect from Jury Service

title: Policies & Procedures
body:
Policies & Procedures
HOW JURORS ARE SUMMONED

The selection and management of jurors is governed by the California Code of Civil Procedure. Prospective jurors for the Santa Barbara County courts are selected randomly from the Voter Registration list and the Department of Motor Vehicles' drivers and identification card-holders lists. From these source lists, the Court creates a master list of prospective jurors. Prospective jurors are selected randomly from that master list to receive a Trial Jury Summons.

Jury summons are sent to groups of prospective jurors selected at random and are mailed approximately 4 weeks prior to the summons date as shown on the form.

JUROR QUALIFICATIONS

To qualify for jury service, one must be:

  1. A citizen of the United States
  2. 18 years of age or older
  3. Resident of Santa Barbara County
  4. Have not been convicted of a felony and currently incarcerated in jail or prison
  5. Have not been convicted of a felony and currently on parole, postrelease community supervision, felony probation, or mandated supervision
  6. Have not been convicted of a felony and required to register as a sex offender pursuant to PC 290
  7. Speak and understand the English language
  8. Not currently serving as a Grand or Trial Juror in any court
  9. Not currently a subject of a conservatorship
EXCUSES/EXEMPTIONS

PEACE OFFICERS as defined only in Sections 830.1, 830.2(a) or 830.33(a) of the Penal Code are exempt. Individuals must request this exemption. Please go to the Superior Court's online jury portal at https://juryservice.sbcourts.org or call the court's automated phone line at 855-955-1103 to submit your request for excuse. Staff will review and process the request. You will be notified if further information is needed to help process your request.

REQUEST FOR EXCUSE

If you receive a summons and you want to be excused, you MUST submit a request via the Superior Court's online jury portal at https://juryservice.sbcourts.org or call the court's automated phone line at 855-955-1103. Staff will review and process the request. You will be notified of the results via email, text message, letter, or phone call.

If you feel you should be permanently excused from jury service due to a medical condition and if you are UNDER AGE 70, you must have a note signed by a medical professional. The note must state you should be PERMANENTLY EXCUSED. You may fax, email, or mail the information to the court.

If you are OVER AGE 70 and feel you should be permanently excused due to a medical condition, you must submit your request via the Superior Court's online jury portal at https://juryservice.sbcourts.org or call the court's automated phone line at 855-955-1103. Staff will review and process the request. You will be notified of the results via email, text message, letter, or phone call. You are not required to submit a note from your medical professional if you have a legitimate medical condition and you are OVER AGE 70.

Inconvenience to a prospective trial juror or an employer is not a legal reason to be excused from jury service. Any employer who interferes with an employee reporting for jury service may be charged with a misdemeanor. (Labor Code Section 230).

FAILURE TO APPEAR

Failure to attend or respond for jury service is a serious matter which may subject you to penalties as prescribed by law, including monetary sanctions (Code of Civil Procedure Section 209).  Santa Barbara Superior Court has implemented a Juror Failure To Appear (FTA) Program with the focus of achieving compliance by improving juror attendance as well as providing education about the importance of participating in this civic obligation.  The ultimate consequence of noncompliance can be personal service of an Order To Show Cause Re Contempt by a Santa Barbara County Sheriff with a date ordering the juror to appear before a Superior Court Judge.  If the juror is found in contempt of court, the judge may order a fine up to $1,000 along with presenting the juror a new summons for a future on call date.  If you have failed to appear for jury service please contact the Jury office immediately.  In Santa Barbara you may call (805) 882-4530, in Santa Maria (805) 614-6464.

POSTPONEMENT OF JURY SERVICE

When summoned for jury service, prospective jurors are placed on-call for approximately five (5) court working days. If you are not available during your on-call period, you may request ONE POSTPONEMENT of your service beginning on a Monday (excluding court holidays) within the next 90 days. You may postpone your service using the Superior Court's online jury portal at https://juryservice.sbcourts.org. Please have your Juror ID number and your PIN number ready. They are located on the front page in the lower left-hand section of your summons. Staff will review and process the request. You will be notified of the results via email, text message, letter, or phone call. If you are unable to submit your request via the online jury portal, you may come to the jury services office and speak with a staff member.

STUDENTS

No person is exempt from service by reason of occupation. Based on their student status, students may request a postponement of their service to the next school break (in this case we will defer past 90 days if necessary).

EMERGENCIES

If you have an emergency on the day you are to report, notify the Jury Services Office. Office hours are from 8 a.m. to 3 p.m., Monday through Friday, excluding holidays. 

  • In Santa Barbara please call (805) 882-4530.
  • In Santa Maria please call (805) 614-6464. 

If a general emergency occurs, such as an earthquake, flood, fire, civil unrest, etc., call 855-955-1103 for instructions concerning jury service.

BADGES

When issued, please wear your juror badge at all times while you are at the courthouse. It is important that people recognize you as a juror. Overhearing statements by attorneys, defendants, or other parties could cause a mistrial.

BREAKS AND END OF DAY

Before going to a courtroom for jury selection, jury staff will keep you informed about breaks. Once you are assigned to a courtroom for jury selection, the judge will inform you of breaks, lunch periods and the time trial will begin and end each day.

DRESS CODE

Business attire is suggested. Jurors are advised to dress in layers as the temperature of the jury assembly areas and courtrooms can be unpredictable. Ties are not required. Be comfortable but avoid extremes in dress. Beach attire such as tank tops, shorts and flip flops are not appropriate for jury service.

JURY DUTY BENEFITS

Employers are not required by law to compensate employees with their regular wages while on jury duty. Many employers do have jury benefits and will continue your wages while you serve. Check with your employer regarding the company policy BEFORE you report for jury service.

NOTE TAKING

You may take notes, but you should not become so involved in note-taking that you miss important points that are being told to you.

AVAILABLE BUS SERVICES
  • For the Santa Barbara court location only, your jury summons may be used as a free MTD bus pass on your first reporting day. Hand the summons to the driver for validation. Check with Jury Services if you are required to return a second day. Please see www.sbmtd.gov for schedules/routes.

  • For bus service within the Santa Maria area, please see the Santa Maria Area Transit (SMAT) website for schedules/routes: www.ci.santa-maria.ca.us/3075.html

  • For bus service between Lompoc and the Santa Ynez Valley to Santa Maria Superior Court or Lompoc Superior Court, please see The Breeze Bus website at www.breezebus.com for schedules/routes, or call 800-417-2137.

  • For bus service between Guadalupe and Santa Maria, please contact The Guadalupe Flyer at (805) 922-8476 for schedules/routes.
PARKING

DO NOT park in spaces for handicapped, car pool, reserved or in spaces with limited time (violators will be ticketed.)

  • SANTA BARBARA:
    The jury parking lot is located at 1019 Garden Street (located between Figueroa & Carrillo Streets). If lot is full, parking is available at the church located at Valerio & Santa Barbara Streets. Parking is in the upper lot only.

The city parking lot on Anacapa Street across from the courthouse is very convenient and the first 75 minutes are free. More downtown Santa Barbara parking information here.

  • SANTA MARIA:

    Courthouse parking is limited.  Free parking is available in the mall parking lot located across the street from the courthouse on the corner of Cook and Miller streets and in surrounding areas. 


  • LOMPOC:
    Upon entering the Civic Center Plaza you will find parking to your left. The court is located to the left of the Police Department.

Parking is limited, so please allow sufficient time.

COMPENSATION

Beginning the second day of jury service (and for each day thereafter) you will be paid fifteen dollars ($15.00) per day, plus thirty-four cents a mile ($0.34), one way mileage from your home to the court (California Code of Civil Procedure Sec. 215). Jurors do not receive any compensation for the first day of service under state law.

Checks for jury service are computed at the completion of the trial to which you were assigned and are mailed to you at your home address. Checks should be received within 4 to 6 weeks after the end of the trial.

Questions regarding jury payment checks should be directed as follows:  For service at Santa Barbara Superior Court, call (805) 882-4530. For service at Santa Maria or Lompoc Superior Court, call (805) 614-6464.

If you are serving on a case and are not required to report for a day or for several days, you will not receive jury fees, credit for service, or written verification of service for those days on which you are not required to report.You are expected to return to work, or notify your employer, any day or days you are not required to report for jury service.

SPECIAL ACCOMODATIONS

If you require special accommodations or have a special situation that is not addressed here, please call your local Jury Services office during regular business hours.


PROOF OF APPEARANCE FOR JURY SERVICE

If you need proof of your appearance for jury service for your employer, a form may be furnished by the jury staff on your first day of service. Should you return a second day for selection or as a sworn juror, a jury staff member, the bailiff, or court clerk can sign your confirmation of appearance on a daily basis. Please bring this form with you each day. You may also login to the Superior Court's online jury portal at https:// juryservice.sbcourts.org to print a letter of attendance for your employer or your records.


QUESTIONS

If you have a question while in the courtroom, ask the bailiff if the question should be answered by the judge. The bailiff will insure that the question is appropriately forwarded. If you cannot hear, are feeling ill or need to leave the courtroom, notify the bailiff and explain your situation.  The bailiff will assist you and will advise the judge accordingly.


SECURITY IN THE COURTHOUSE / JURY ASSEMBLY BUILDING

No weapons of any kind are allowed in the courthouse, including courtrooms and the jury assembly building. This includes mace and/or pepper spray. If you are carrying any weapons, even for your own protection, please leave them in your car or at home. All divisions of the Santa Barbara Superior Court including Santa Maria, Lompoc and Solvang conduct weapons screening.  This screening is similar to what you would experience at any airport.  Your person and property are subject to search and x-ray examination.  Please notify the guards if you have a medical condition which requires special accommodation when walking through a metal detector.  For the full list of prohibited items, click here.

All jurors and prospective jurors may be required to go through the metal detectors when directed to a courtroom.  When reporting for jury duty, please allow extra time to go through the weapons screening line.


TERM OF SERVICE

California law provides that you may be summoned for jury service once every twelve (12) months. You will be placed on-call for approximately five (5) court working days. You will be called to report during that period only if there is a trial for which a jury is needed. When you are sent to a courtroom as a prospective juror and you are chosen as an actual trial or alternate juror, your jury obligation will be fulfilled upon the conclusion of deliberation. If you are not chosen as a juror or alternate, your jury service will be fulfilled upon your dismissal by the court (i.e.: you are excused by challenge) or upon the swearing of the jury, even if you were not called into the jury box for questioning.


TRIAL DURATION

Trials are of varying lengths. Cases in Santa Barbara County Superior Court may typically range from one to six days, or even longer in many cases. The trial judge will advise you of the trial duration and may excuse or postpone you from serving on a particular case if your service would amount to an extreme hardship.


WAITING

Due to the nature of jury service and court processes, there are often periods of waiting. We suggest bringing something to read. There are brief recesses throughout the day, and you will have at least one hour for lunch.

title: Reporting Instructions
body:
Reporting Instructions

If you have received a Trial Jury Summons, examine the entire document carefully for the following information:

  • Summons Date
  • Jury Group Number
  • Juror ID Number
  • PIN Number
  • 24 hour information phone line

You will need to check the Superior Court's online jury portal or call the court's automated phone line at 855-955-1103 after 5:30 PM the evening prior to your summons date for the reporting instructions for your group. You will need to have your Juror ID number and PIN number available.

You must access the Superior Court's online jury portal at https://juryservice.sbcourts.org or call the court's automated phone line at 855-955-1103 to check for your status as directed during your on-call period to determine if you are required to report for service. Please have your summons handy when calling. You will need to enter your specific Juror ID Number and PIN Number to access your record. You will be placed on call for approximately five (5) court days. If directed to report for jury service you MUST bring your summons with you when you report and you MUST be on time. If you are not directed to report for service during your on-call period, you will be released as instructed on the recorded message or the court's website.
